paragraphs.text:
%md
# Basic Machine Learning using DBMS_PREDICTIVE_ANALYTICS

One of the capabilities available in the Oracle Database is the DBMS_PREDICTIVE_ANALYTICS PL/SQL Package.  Predictive analytics is a technology that captures data mining processes in simple routines.  Sometimes called "one-click data mining," predictive analytics simplifies and automates the data mining process.

Predictive analytics uses data mining technology, but knowledge of data mining is not needed to use predictive analytics. You can use predictive analytics simply by specifying an operation to perform on your data. You do not need to create or use explicit mining models or to deeply understand the mining functions and algorithms.

There are three Oracle Predictive Analytics Operations:

- EXPLAIN: Explains how individual predictors (columns) affect the variation of values in a target column

- PREDICT: For each case (row), predicts the values in a target column

- PROFILE: Creates a set of rules for cases (rows) that imply the same target value


Documentation Links:
https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/18/dmapi/introduction-to-oracle-data-mining.html
https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/18/arpls/DBMS_PREDICTIVE_ANALYTICS.html

result.msg:
Basic Machine Learning using DBMS_PREDICTIVE_ANALYTICS

Sometimes called “one-click data mining,” predictive analytics simplifies and automates the data mining process.

Predictive analytics uses data mining technology, but knowledge of data mining is not needed to use predictive analytics. You can use predictive analytics simply by specifying an operation to perform on your data. You do not need to create or use explicit mining models or to deeply understand the mining functions and algorithms.

There are three Oracle Predictive Analytics Operations:

  • EXPLAIN: Explains how individual predictors (columns) affect the variation of values in a target column

  • PREDICT: For each case (row), predicts the values in a target column

  • PROFILE: Creates a set of rules for cases (rows) that imply the same target value

Documentation Links:
https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/18/dmapi/introduction-to-oracle-data-mining.html
https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/18/arpls/DBMS_PREDICTIVE_ANALYTICS.html

paragraphs.text:
%md 
# EXPLAIN

The EXPLAIN procedure identifies the attributes that are important in explaining the variation in values of a target column.  The records in a specified data table/view are used by the procedure to train a model that calculates the attribute importance. 

The EXPLAIN procedure creates a result table that lists the attributes in order of their explanatory power.  The results table column EXPLANATORY_VALUE indicates how useful the column is for determining the value of the explained column. Higher values indicate greater explanatory power. Value can range from 0 to 1.

An explanatory power value of 0 implies there is no useful correlation between the column's values and the explain column's values. An explanatory power of 1 implies perfect correlation; such columns should be eliminated from consideration for PREDICT. In practice, an explanatory power equal to 1 is rarely returned. 


Link:
https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/18/arpls/DBMS_PREDICTIVE_ANALYTICS.html#GUID-5A5DEECD-6521-4D8D-BA0D-D49EE1194A3C

result.msg:
EXPLAIN

The EXPLAIN procedure identifies the attributes that are important in explaining the variation in values of a target column. The records in a specified data table/view are used by the procedure to train a model that calculates the attribute importance.

The EXPLAIN procedure creates a result table that lists the attributes in order of their explanatory power. The results table column EXPLANATORY_VALUE indicates how useful the column is for determining the value of the explained column. Higher values indicate greater explanatory power. Value can range from 0 to 1.

An explanatory power value of 0 implies there is no useful correlation between the column's values and the explain column's values. An explanatory power of 1 implies perfect correlation; such columns should be eliminated from consideration for PREDICT. In practice, an explanatory power equal to 1 is rarely returned.

Link:
https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/18/arpls/DBMS_PREDICTIVE_ANALYTICS.html#GUID-5A5DEECD-6521-4D8D-BA0D-D49EE1194A3C

paragraphs.title: Script to rank columns in order of influence of explaining the HOME_THEATER_PACKAGE column
paragraphs.text:
%script

--use a view to select from the sample SH schema
CREATE OR REPLACE VIEW ml_data_view
AS
SELECT * FROM SH.supplementary_demographics;

--drop result table if necessary
DROP TABLE demographics_explain_result;

--Perform EXPLAIN operation 
BEGIN 
    DBMS_PREDICTIVE_ANALYTICS.EXPLAIN( 
        data_table_name      => 'ml_data_view', 
        explain_column_name  => 'home_theater_package', 
        result_table_name    => 'demographics_explain_result'); 
END; 
/ 
--Display results 
SELECT * FROM demographics_explain_result;

paragraphs.title: Query to display columns influence/explanatory rank graphically
paragraphs.text:
%sql
SELECT * FROM demographics_explain_result 
WHERE explanatory_value>0 
ORDER BY rank;

%md
### Assessing the output of the EXPLAIN

The above results show that the Y_BOX_GAMES, YRS_RESIDENCE, and HOUSEHOLD_SIZE columns are the best predictors of HOME_THEATER_PACKAGE column.

result.msg:
Assessing the output of the EXPLAIN

The above results show that the Y_BOX_GAMES, YRS_RESIDENCE, and HOUSEHOLD_SIZE columns are the best predictors of HOME_THEATER_PACKAGE column.

paragraphs.text:
%md
# PREDICT

The PREDICT procedure predicts the values of a target column.  It can work with categorical (classification problems) or numerical (regression problems) target columns.

The records of the data table are used by the procedure to train and test a model that makes the predictions. The PREDICT procedure creates a result table that contains a predicted target value for every record.

The proceudre returns an output parameter (accuracy) that returns the predictive confidence, a measure of the accuracy of the predicted values. The predictive confidence for a categorical target is the most common target value; the predictive confidence for a numerical target is the mean.

For the results table,
PREDICTION: The predicted value of the target column for the given case.
PROBABILITY: For classification (categorical target), the probability of the prediction. For regression problems (numerical target), this column contains NULL. 

Links:
https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/18/arpls/DBMS_PREDICTIVE_ANALYTICS.html#GUID-2B5B965D-3F2E-48F4-8373-21C1B7BDCE97

result.msg:
PREDICT

The PREDICT procedure predicts the values of a target column. It can work with categorical (classification problems) or numerical (regression problems) target columns.

The records of the data table are used by the procedure to train and test a model that makes the predictions. The PREDICT procedure creates a result table that contains a predicted target value for every record.

The proceudre returns an output parameter (accuracy) that returns the predictive confidence, a measure of the accuracy of the predicted values. The predictive confidence for a categorical target is the most common target value; the predictive confidence for a numerical target is the mean.

For the results table,
PREDICTION: The predicted value of the target column for the given case.
PROBABILITY: For classification (categorical target), the probability of the prediction. For regression problems (numerical target), this column contains NULL.

Links:
https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/18/arpls/DBMS_PREDICTIVE_ANALYTICS.html#GUID-2B5B965D-3F2E-48F4-8373-21C1B7BDCE97

paragraphs.title: Example to PREDICT whether each customer has an affinity card
paragraphs.text:
%script

--we will split our data into a TRAIN and TEST dataset

--use a TRAIN view and pick 60% of the rows
CREATE OR REPLACE VIEW ml_data_view_train
AS
SELECT * FROM SH.supplementary_demographics SAMPLE(60) SEED (1);

--use a TEST view with the leftover data
CREATE OR REPLACE VIEW ml_data_view_test
AS
SELECT * FROM SH.supplementary_demographics MINUS SELECT * FROM ml_data_view_train;

--create a master view with the target column null for the TEST data
CREATE OR REPLACE VIEW ml_data_view AS
select a.cust_id,
a.EDUCATION ,
a.OCCUPATION ,
a.HOUSEHOLD_SIZE ,
a.YRS_RESIDENCE ,
a.BULK_PACK_DISKETTES ,
a.FLAT_PANEL_MONITOR ,
a.HOME_THEATER_PACKAGE ,
a.BOOKKEEPING_APPLICATION ,
a.PRINTER_SUPPLIES ,
a.Y_BOX_GAMES ,
a.OS_DOC_SET_KANJI ,
a.COMMENTS ,
a.AFFINITY_CARD
FROM ml_data_view_train a
UNION ALL
select a.cust_id,
a.EDUCATION ,
a.OCCUPATION ,
a.HOUSEHOLD_SIZE ,
a.YRS_RESIDENCE ,
a.BULK_PACK_DISKETTES ,
a.FLAT_PANEL_MONITOR ,
a.HOME_THEATER_PACKAGE ,
a.BOOKKEEPING_APPLICATION ,
a.PRINTER_SUPPLIES ,
a.Y_BOX_GAMES ,
a.OS_DOC_SET_KANJI ,
a.COMMENTS ,
null
FROM ml_data_view_test a;


--drop result table if necessary
DROP TABLE demographics_predict_result;

--Perform PREDICT operation 
DECLARE 
    v_accuracy NUMBER(10,9); 
BEGIN 
    DBMS_PREDICTIVE_ANALYTICS.PREDICT( 
        accuracy             => v_accuracy, 
        data_table_name      => 'ml_data_view', 
        case_id_column_name  => 'cust_id', 
        target_column_name   => 'affinity_card', 
        result_table_name    => 'demographics_predict_result'); 
    DBMS_OUTPUT.PUT_LINE('Accuracy = ' || v_accuracy); 
END; 
/

--Display first 10 predictions
SELECT * FROM demographics_predict_result WHERE rownum < 10;

paragraphs.title: Query to compare test data actual to predicted values
paragraphs.text:
%sql 
select t.cust_id, t.affinity_card, p.prediction, p.probability
FROM ml_data_view_test t, demographics_predict_result p
WHERE t.cust_id =p.cust_id
AND rownum<100;

%sql
select 'results' results, sum(case when affinity_card=prediction then 1 else 0 end) num_correct,
  sum(case when affinity_card!=prediction then 1 else 0 end) num_incorrect
from (select t.cust_id, t.affinity_card, p.prediction, p.probability
FROM ml_data_view_test t, demographics_predict_result p
WHERE t.cust_id =p.cust_id) test_results

%md
### Assessing the output of the PREDICT example

The above results show that the PREDICT has correctly predicted that the customer has an affinity card more often than predicting incorrectly.

result.msg:
Assessing the output of the PREDICT example

The above results show that the PREDICT has correctly predicted that the customer has an affinity card more often than predicting incorrectly.

paragraphs.text:
%md 
# Extra Credit: PROFILE

The final DBMS_PREDICTIVE_ANALYTICS operation is PROFILE.  This is listed as extra credit, because it will take some additonal effort to interpret the results as the results are provided in XML format.  You should consult the PROFILE documentation to help you understand it.

result.msg:
Extra Credit: PROFILE

The final DBMS_PREDICTIVE_ANALYTICS operation is PROFILE. This is listed as extra credit, because it will take some additonal effort to interpret the results as the results are provided in XML format. You should consult the PROFILE documentation to help you understand it.

paragraphs.text:
%md
# PROFILE 

The PROFILE procedure generates a list of rules that describe the cases (records) from the input data.

For example, if a target column CHURN has values 'Yes' and 'No', PROFILE generates a set of rules describing the expected outcomes.  

The PROFILE procedure creates a result table that specifies rules (profiles) and their corresponding target values.  Each profile includes a rule, record count, and a score distribution.  The rules are expressed in XML syntax, so you likely will use SQL/XML functions like extract() and extractvalue() to work with the results.


Links:
https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/18/arpls/DBMS_PREDICTIVE_ANALYTICS.html#GUID-D6636F50-FACA-4658-ADE0-7EAF3725E0BE

result.msg:
PROFILE

The PROFILE procedure generates a list of rules that describe the cases (records) from the input data.

For example, if a target column CHURN has values 'Yes' and 'No', PROFILE generates a set of rules describing the expected outcomes.

The PROFILE procedure creates a result table that specifies rules (profiles) and their corresponding target values. Each profile includes a rule, record count, and a score distribution. The rules are expressed in XML syntax, so you likely will use SQL/XML functions like extract() and extractvalue() to work with the results.

Links:
https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/18/arpls/DBMS_PREDICTIVE_ANALYTICS.html#GUID-D6636F50-FACA-4658-ADE0-7EAF3725E0BE

paragraphs.title: Example to identify PROFILE rules for that affinity_card based on the household_size and yrs_residence columns
paragraphs.text:
%script


--use a view to select from the sample SH schema
--Note: we are limiting ourselves to 2 columns (HOUSEHOLD_SIZE and YRS_RESIDENCE) to make interpreting the output easier
CREATE OR REPLACE VIEW ml_data_view
AS
SELECT 
--a.OCCUPATION ,
a.HOUSEHOLD_SIZE ,
a.YRS_RESIDENCE  ,
--a.EDUCATION ,
/* a.BULK_PACK_DISKETTES ,
a.FLAT_PANEL_MONITOR ,
a.HOME_THEATER_PACKAGE ,
a.BOOKKEEPING_APPLICATION ,
a.PRINTER_SUPPLIES ,
a.Y_BOX_GAMES ,
a.OS_DOC_SET_KANJI , */
a.AFFINITY_CARD
FROM SH.supplementary_demographics a;

--drop result table if necessary
DROP TABLE demographics_profile_result;

BEGIN
    DBMS_PREDICTIVE_ANALYTICS.PROFILE(
         DATA_TABLE_NAME    => 'ml_data_view',
         TARGET_COLUMN_NAME => 'affinity_card',
         RESULT_TABLE_NAME  => 'demographics_profile_result');
END;
/
--Display results 
SELECT a.profile_id, extractvalue(a.description, '/SimpleRule/@score') target_value, a.record_count, extract(a.description, '/SimpleRule/CompoundPredicate').getstringval() rules
--, a.description.getstringval()
FROM demographics_profile_result a;

result.msg:
View ML_DATA_VIEW created.


---------------------------

Table DEMOGRAPHICS_PROFILE_RESULT dropped.


---------------------------

PL/SQL procedure successfully completed.


---------------------------
PROFILE_ID   TARGET_VALUE   RECORD_COUNT   RULES                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     
           1 0                         483 <CompoundPredicate booleanOperator="and"><SimpleSetPredicate field="HOUSEHOLD_SIZE" booleanOperator="isIn"><Array type="string">"3" "4-5" </Array></SimpleSetPredicate><SimplePredicate field="YRS_RESIDENCE" operator="lessOrEqual" value="3.5"/></CompoundPredicate>                                
           2 1                        1523 <CompoundPredicate booleanOperator="and"><SimpleSetPredicate field="HOUSEHOLD_SIZE" booleanOperator="isIn"><Array type="string">"3" "4-5" </Array></SimpleSetPredicate><SimplePredicate field="YRS_RESIDENCE" operator="greaterThan" value="3.5"/></CompoundPredicate>                                
           3 0                        1427 <CompoundPredicate booleanOperator="and"><SimpleSetPredicate field="HOUSEHOLD_SIZE" booleanOperator="isIn"><Array type="string">"1" "2" "6-8" "9+" </Array></SimpleSetPredicate><SimplePredicate field="YRS_RESIDENCE" operator="lessOrEqual" value="3.5"/></CompoundPredicate>   
           4 0                        1067 <CompoundPredicate booleanOperator="and"><SimpleSetPredicate field="HOUSEHOLD_SIZE" booleanOperator="isIn"><Array type="string">"1" "2" "6-8" "9+" </Array></SimpleSetPredicate><SimplePredicate field="YRS_RESIDENCE" operator="greaterThan" value="3.5"/></CompoundPredicate>   



---------------------------

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Assessing the output of the PROFILE operation

In the example above, we are identifying profile rules for the HOUSEHOLD_SIZE and YRS_RESIDENCE columns that can predict the AFFINITY_CARD column.

Here is a snippet of sample output (your output might vary):


    PROFILE_ID   TARGET_VALUE   RECORD_COUNT   RULES                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     
           1             0             483     <CompoundPredicate booleanOperator="and"><SimpleSetPredicate field="HOUSEHOLD_SIZE" booleanOperator="isIn"><Array type="string">"3" "4-5" </Array></SimpleSetPredicate><SimplePredicate field="YRS_RESIDENCE" operator="lessOrEqual" value="3.5"/></CompoundPredicate>                                
           2             1            1523     <CompoundPredicate booleanOperator="and"><SimpleSetPredicate field="HOUSEHOLD_SIZE" booleanOperator="isIn"><Array type="string">"3" "4-5" </Array></SimpleSetPredicate><SimplePredicate field="YRS_RESIDENCE" operator="greaterThan" value="3.5"/></CompoundPredicate>                                
           

What the above sample output tells us is that the first rule (with PROFILE_ID=1) is saying that it predicts that the AFFINITY_CARD column will be 1 when HOUSEHOLD_SIZE is in ('3','4-5') and YRS_RESIDENCE is <= 3.5.

result.msg:

In the example above, we are identifying profile rules for the HOUSEHOLD_SIZE and YRS_RESIDENCE columns that can predict the AFFINITY_CARD column.

Here is a snippet of sample output (your output might vary):

PROFILE_ID   TARGET_VALUE   RECORD_COUNT   RULES                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     
       1             0             483     <CompoundPredicate booleanOperator="and"><SimpleSetPredicate field="HOUSEHOLD_SIZE" booleanOperator="isIn"><Array type="string">"3" "4-5" </Array></SimpleSetPredicate><SimplePredicate field="YRS_RESIDENCE" operator="lessOrEqual" value="3.5"/></CompoundPredicate>                                
       2             1            1523     <CompoundPredicate booleanOperator="and"><SimpleSetPredicate field="HOUSEHOLD_SIZE" booleanOperator="isIn"><Array type="string">"3" "4-5" </Array></SimpleSetPredicate><SimplePredicate field="YRS_RESIDENCE" operator="greaterThan" value="3.5"/></CompoundPredicate>

What the above sample output tells us is that the first rule (with PROFILE_ID=1) is saying that it predicts that the AFFINITY_CARD column will be 1 when HOUSEHOLD_SIZE is in ('3','4-5') and YRS_RESIDENCE is <= 3.5.

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Next Steps

- Experiment with DBMS_PREDICTIVE_ANALYTICS with your data
- Review the Oracle Database Data Mining documentation: https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/18/dmapi/introduction-to-oracle-data-mining.html
- Look at the DBMS_DATA_MINING sample notebooes in the Oracle ML Notebook Gallery
